Expectation1: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation1: Before starting structural work, the carpenter needs to inspect and maintain tools and equipment to ensure safety and efficiency
Situation2: They plan to attend a family ceremony, making sure to arrive on time and wear appropriate attire.
Story: I stood in my workshop, the scent of sawdust thick in the air, my hands running over the handles of my tools. Today, before starting the new structural work, I needed to inspect and maintain every piece of equipment—safety protocols were strict, and I knew too well the risks of neglect. But as I checked the teeth of my saw, my phone buzzed with a reminder: the family ceremony was in just a few hours. As a Hindu, it was my duty to be there, dressed in clean, traditional attire, to honor my ancestors and join my family in prayer. My mother had called twice already, reminding me not to be late. I glanced at the clock, feeling the pressure mount. If I rushed the inspection, I could make it on time, but I’d be risking safety on site. If I did the job thoroughly, I’d be late for the ceremony, disappointing my family and disrespecting our traditions. My heart pounded as I weighed the demands of my work against the pull of my faith, caught between two worlds that both expected my full devotion.
